description: From Middle English nodden, probably from an unrecorded Old English *hnodian (“to nod, shake the head”), from Proto-Germanic *hnudōną (“to beat, rivet, pound, push”), from Proto-Indo-European *kendʰ-, from *ken- (“to scratch, scrape, rub”). Compare Old High German hnotōn (“to shake”), hnutten (“to shake, rattle, vibrate”) (> modern dialectal German notteln, nütteln (“to rock, move back and forth”)), Icelandic hnjóða (“to rivet, clinch”).

entries.meaning: An instance of inclining the head up and down, as to indicate agreement, or as a cursory greeting.
A reference or allusion to something.

examples: For the fifth time in her career she received a Grammy nod, she has yet to win the award.
The plan is expected to get the nod from councillors at the next meeting.

verbs.description: nod (third-person singular simple present nods, present participle nodding, simple past and past participle nodded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To incline the head up and down, as to indicate agreement.
(transitive, intransitive) To briefly incline the head downwards as a cursory greeting.
(transitive, intransitive) To sway, move up and down.
examples: By every wind that nods the mountain pine.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a mistake by being temporarily inattentive or tired
(transitive, intransitive, soccer) To head; to strike the ball with one's head.
examples: Jones nods the ball back to his goalkeeper.

Though the title nods to the Italian neo-realist classic Bicycle Thieves—and Cyril, much like the father and son in that movie, spends much of his time tracking down the oft-stolen possession—The Kid With A Bike isn’t about the bike as something essential to his livelihood, but as his sole connection to the freedom and play of childhood itself.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To fall asleep while under the influence of opiates.
